title: pub reopen lockdown hand flowers michelin star safety
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Plus, a salon owner and pub landlords explain how they’re adapting to the new normalIn association with the UK GovernmentLast weekend, salons, bars and restaurants across the country reopened their doors to customers after more than three months of closure.Though detailed UK Government guidelines and new safety measures may have altered the experience of a haircut or meal out, business owners have worked hard to implement rigorous safety measures while ensuring the public can start to feel a sense of normality once again.Here, chef Tom Kerridge, pub owners Colin Steele and Jade Windsor, and salon owner Sarah Bentley explain how they’re keeping staff and customers alike safe…Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTom Kerridge, chef owner at The Hand &amp FlowersTom Kerridge’s passion for the beautiful town of Marlow, Buckinghamshire, is just as strong as ever. As well as two Michelin-starred pubs – The Hand &amp Flowers and The Coach – he also opened a traditional butcher and founded Pub in the Park, the biggest food and music festival tour in the UK.During lockdown, staff from Kerridge’s businesses were volunteering to help a new charity called Meals from Marlow which delivers free food to NHS staff, key workers and people in need. This started small in early April and with support from over 1,000 donors, it recently ended up serving its 75,000th meal.From 4 July, both The Hand &amp Flowers and The Coach have reopened fully in Marlow to welcome back hungry diners.The team have prepared a comprehensive Covid-19 policy document with a number of measures to protect the health and safety of guests and staff. Measures include daily staff temperature checks, hands-free antibacterial gel dispensers, one-way systems, private sole-use of bathrooms, cleaning touchpoints and toilets every 20 minutes, and even sanitising deliveries.Kerridge is also working with a company that provides protection against a wide range of pathogens, including Covid-19, using a sanitising treatment applied through fogging machines to provide an even coat on all surfaces, followed by manual application to hot spots, such as door handles.Form a bubble with a one-adult householdVisit your local salon, restaurant or bar, following UK Government guidelinesMeet in private gardens with up to six peopleTravel on public transport without a face covering or maskShare a car with people outside of your householdFor more information, visit gov.ukcoronavirus“Welcoming, safeguarding and taking care of others is at the very heart of what we do, says Kerridge. The last few months have been such a challenging time and we have been eagerly waiting to establish a little normality back into everyone’s lives, and get back to what we do best – providing great hospitality and food.”Kerridge's pubs have also been altered to make sure that spacing is as per UK Government guidelines. Partitions have been placed to ensure people have privacy and are able to enjoy their experience in the same way as before.Following the success of Meals from Marlow, it has now become a permanent charity and is set to provide 30,000+ meals a year to local people. “I know the people of Marlow are a very generous group but I’m astonished by the speed and the level of kindness, says Kerridge. Thank you, Marlow, I’m proud of you.”Colin Steele and Jade Windsor, pub landlords of the Falcon InnColin Steele and Jade Windsor, pictured below, took over the Falcon Inn five months before lockdown, restoring the pub as a community hub at the heart of the village of Fawley, Hampshire. After coronavirus threw a ner in the works, they were eager to reopen last weekend. “We have social distancing, hand sanitisers and a booking system, so our locals get a guaranteed spot,” says Windsor.The couple made the most of the lockdown by revamping the pub, painting the interiors and outside fencing, and putting up a pergola in the garden for some weather protection. “Because of lockdown we had the time to give the garden the love and attention it really needed,” says Steele. “Painting the fence outside has meant that we've been able to interact with the village as they walk past. We've been trying to bring that community spirit back.” To keep business going, they opened their car park for plant sales and teamed up with local company HMS Spirits to serve takeaway cocktails on Friday nights, which they will continue on weekends throughout the summer. “It kept us doing what we love, says Windsor, and keeping in contact with our customers.” They also recruited a chef with the goal of making back some of the lost income from closure and the now-reduced capacity that allows for distancing. Where they once accommodated 150 inside, now they can host 40. The team have ramped up hygiene measures: doors are wiped every half hour screens at the bar and face shields protect staff. Additional outdoor seating means that everyone is seated, and a new app will enable customers to order food from their tables. “We're a family-run business and everyone just wants us to succeed,” says Steele.Windsor adds: “I'm sure we will come across a few issues, it’s something that no one's ever had to deal with before. I want my pub back the way it was more than anyone, but we've all got to deal with it together.”Sarah Bentley, owner of The Cutting Room unisex salon As a small village salon that’s been open for 16 years, it’s little wonder that The Cutting Room’s loyal clientele had been keenly anticipating its reopening after temporarily closing back in March.A tight-knit team with great customer relationships, Bentley and her employees were excited to get back to a sense of normality. After a meeting last week, they felt reassured about the safety precautions put in place for their return. “It was a bit of relief coming back from staff training and just seeing everybody’s face light up and looking forward to being back,” she says. “We’ve had Zoom meetings discussing all the guidelines.”The salon may have been closed, but plenty was going on in the background to ensure that the premises and the team were as prepared as possible for a safe reopening.For example, they worked hard to keep customers informed about changes to their haircutting experience: as well as the salon now being appointment-only, clients have been informed that they are not able to enter the premises before their appointment, as well being asked to wear a face covering.“Because we are such a small salon, we have screens up between all our sections,” Bentley explains, adding that their booking and payment system has been made completely contactless.Though refreshments or magazines can no longer be provided, The Cutting Room has set up its outdoor space for clients to sit in a socially-distanced manner.The Cutting Room's kit used has also changed: “We’ve got disposable gowns, towels – everybody’s got all their completely own equipment it’s all labelled in their name – their own trollies, Bentley adds.Ultimately, safety is The Cutting Room’s number-one priority. “It’s there to keep us and the clients and my staff safe – and if I felt that they weren’t safe, I would shut the salon tomorrow,” Bentley says. “Everybody’s health comes first.Keeping you safe: a selection of guidelines for UK businesses All businesses are required to be Covid-19-secure in order to help protect their staff and customers. Here are some of the guidelines that salons, pubs and restaurants have been provided with:All businesses will have conducted a risk assessmentThorough and enhanced cleaning facilities will be available for staff and customersBookings will be limited to ensure social distancing and risk mitigationCustomers will be provided with guidance prior to their visitWorkers in continuous close contact to clients, such as hairdressers, will wear visors to promote safetyStaff will be split into teams or shift groups where possible to limit contactIndoor and outdoor seating will be reconfigured to maintain social distancing guidelinesStaggering entry times and introducing one-way systems throughout venuesContact between kitchen staff and front of house staff will be minimisedTo find out more about business guidelines, visit gov.ukguidanceworking-safely-during-coronavirus-covid-19Want to bookmark your favourite articles and stories to read or reference later? title: uk business economy reopen great inspirations
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The UK Government's GREAT Inspirations campaign shines a light on British companies, big and small, who continue to rise to the&nbspchallenges presented by coronavirusIn association with the UK GovernmentThroughout the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, many businesses across the UK have gone above and beyond in rising to the many challenges presented by this unprecedented crisis and pitching in with the national effort.As lockdown restrictions are being eased, reopening non-essential retail is the next step to restoring people's livelihoods and kick-starting the British economy.Meet four UK businesses, a erse quartet of GREAT Inspirations, who have not only done remarkable things for the community at large during lockdown, but who are also embracing a return to trading – inspiring shoppers to adjust to the new normal and ring the tills again.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFounded in 1918, O’Neills, pictured above and main image, went through more than 100 years without laying off staff or shutting a single factory. But when coronavirus hit in March, Ireland’s biggest sportswear brand had to break the habit of a lifetime and sack its entire 750-strong workforce at its Strabane factory due to the lockdown.With sports events cancelled or postponed, orders from teams and retailers vanished.However, the company was thrown a surprise lifeline when, a day after announcing the layoffs, the Western Health and Social Care Trust approached O’Neills on a Friday about fulfilling a shortage of scrubs to safeguard frontline NHS workers.Factory staff spent that weekend making sample scrubs. By the Monday, O’Neills had secured an order for 10,000 sets of maroon tops and trousers for GPs at a coronavirus testing centre at Altnagelvin Area Hospital, Londonderry.As a result, the company rehired 150 workers immediately. It has since brought back more than 400 staff overall as orders from other health trusts across Northern Ireland grew, with the remaining 350 employees being furloughed.The company now produces some 10,000 sets of scrubs a week. Managing director Kieran Kennedy, a veteran of 41 years at the business, says employees have been supportive of the switch from making sporting goods.“We are a close-knit community in Strabane. Many employees know people who work in the NHS and they want to give back,” he explains. “We could either feel sorry for ourselves or be productive and take a bite at the cherry. Without the NHS orders, we would have had no sales and no cash flow. The scrubs kept the show on the road.”Kennedy says the move outside the company’s traditional business area has been relatively easy. For instance, O’Neills had stockpiled a six-month supply of yarn – the raw material for the scrubs and other clothing – from China to hedge against Brexit uncertainty. The company knits the scrubs at its Strabane factory, then dyes and coats them with anti-viral substances at its production plant in Dublin.Workers on the factory floors are social distancing, as well as wearing face masks, sanitising their hands and having their temperature checked.Kennedy is upbeat on the company’s future prospects, noting that big sporting fixtures are returning, which should boost sales and enable him to rehire more workers. But for the foreseeable future, Kennedy plans to continue producing protective gear – an unexpected new revenue stream.   The gift shop owner donating Happy Bags to localsWhen Sarah Lloyd Williams, pictured above, had to temporarily close her quirky little gift shop in Frome on 22 March, she had no idea what she was going to do with the time ahead.At first, Lloyd Williams relished the opportunity to spend every day with her dog, Chester, taking him with other dogs out for walks. However, by nature, she is a hands-on person and soon realised she needed to find something to fill her time other than dog walking and cleaning.She had found out that someone local to her had been having a hard time. “I knew this lady slightly and wondered if there was anything I could do to help, Lloyd Williams explains. I didn’t feel that I knew her enough to contact her offering assistance, so instead I decided to leave a little gift on her doorstep.” She called it a Happy Bag, containing a copy of The Happy Newspaper (a quarterly newspaper by Emily Coxhead containing nothing but good news), a chocolate bar, bath bomb and a little note.This good deed went down very well: the recipient messaged Lloyd Williams to ask if she could buy a Happy Bag for her friend. “I didn’t want any money, Lloyd Williams explains. This was something small that I could do with items that I already sell in Figgins, so I delivered a Happy Bag to her friend and it went from there.”She ended up delivering a number of bags in the local area and it led to doing a few other little things for people, such as picking up medicines, shopping and more dog walking.For Lloyd Williams, this became a lovely way to connect with people that she barely knew, or had never met before, and it made lockdown much easier to navigate: “Giving away some Happy Bags certainly made me feel much happier. It’s a tiny thing, but sometimes that’s all it takes to make someone’s day,” she says.Figgins has now reopened, with Lloyd Williams taking steps to make sure her shop is safer with a screen, hand sanitising stations, floor stickers and limiting the number of people in the shop at any one time. Lloyd Williams is also donating a Happy Bag every week to someone in the local community.At the start of lockdown, Andy Hibbert, above, transformed his car-sharing business.Launched in 2017, Car &amp Away had enabled holidaymakers to rent out their cars from Gatwick and Bristol Airports while they were away, but when the coronavirus forced airports to close, business plummeted.The CEO from south west London quickly decided to use the business' existing assets to help key workers and launched a new service: Karshare.“We had this burgeoning desire for people to rent their car from home because it was sat there doing nothing,” Hibbert explains. “But then Covid came along. As a business we were stranded. We thought: this is ridiculous. We have all the systems in place to enable us to share cars. Why don't we launch the car-sharing concept where owners donate their cars to critical-care workers and people who are supporting the most vulnerable in our community?”At the peak of the pandemic, travelling by car minimised viral spread on public transport and limited key workers’ exposure, while making their journeys easier at a stressful time. Karshare encouraged members of the public in Bristol, Brighton, London, Manchester and Leeds to donate their cars for a week to NHS staff and volunteer organisations. The cars were then deep cleaned and matched to local key workers in need of transport.Insurance and road coverage were provided for free, and the owner received a full tank of petrol as a thank you.Impressively, 700 cars have since been donated – including to 31 London NHS trusts – with a total 19,000 days of use. Leasing company ALD donated 30 new cars in Bristol. “We were overwhelmed initially about the donations,” says Hibbert.One key worker who benefited was Michaela Morris, deputy chief operating officer at the NHS Nightingale Hospital London in Docklands. “She was put into a hotel and told she needs to be on call 247, so we quickly found her a car,” says Hibbert. “It’s remarkable that she has been able to continue that work because of the generosity of the public.”Karshare also helped a care worker who had only been able to reach a couple of vulnerable patients a day on his bicycle. When he was loaned a car he could reach up to 11 – and save more lives.While Karshare is now focusing efforts on making the business profitable again, it is also inviting donations to critical workers and will ask for contributions to cover the insurance. Karshare is also being extended to the wider community, allowing people to rent their cars from home.“There are financial pressures for people,” adds Hibbert, “yet they've got an asset on their driveway that could really help.”The distillery that swapped gin for hand sanitiserIn the midst of a global pandemic, constrained by lockdown, a fledging gin brand was surrounded by alcohol with no bars open to supply. But reports of hand sanitiser shortages hit the headlines and gave the team an idea.Sean Roche launched Aintree Gin in December 2019. An organic, craft spirit, it takes its name from its home in Merseyside – a village renowned for its famous racecourse which hosts the historic Grand National.By spring, Roche and the team had introduced the gin to over 30 establishments around Liverpool. They were gearing up for the steeplechase, but lockdown put paid to their plans. “As soon as everything started to shut … all of our income went down to zero,” Roche says.Realising online sales would be key, the team started building a website – then they had a brainwave. “News reports started to regularly mention how shortages of… alcohol-based sanitiser were putting NHS and care workers at risk,” says Roche. “We knew that because we were already using pure alcohol to make our gin, we could change our production line to make sanitiser.”Their first batch was ready within weeks. Word got out and, soon after, they were inundated with requests from care homes, hospitals and more, Roche recalls.Volunteers were recruited and more than 600 litres were donated in six weeks. But as supplies ran low, and with no money coming in, the enterprise became financially unviable. “We had two choices,” says Roche. “Stop – or start selling something.”Opting for the latter, new containers were ordered and labels designed so the sanitiser could be sold online. They started offering a range of PPE products too, from face shields to masks. “This created a revenue stream that allowed us to continue,” adds Roche.A PPE pop-up and free hand sanitiser stations at an Asda store followed. “We donated more than we made in profit over the period,” Roche admits.Today, sales are going strong. As businesses look to reopen, many are turning to Aintree Gin for their sanitisation requirements – and also the brand’s primary product. They now aim to supply as many bars and restaurants as possible, and get into supermarkets as well.To read about more inspiring GREAT stories, visit greatbritaincampaigninspirationsWant to bookmark your favourite articles and stories to read or reference later? title: sun says sunak primark government
story: Too many thriving companies are on the verge of gleefully accepting the handout, seeing it as free cash.But the money Rishi Sunak is giving to employers to take back workers comes straight from the taxpayer — so it would be a crying shameit went to waste lining the pockets of managers whose businesses aren’t in jeopardy.We see why Mr Sunak offered a lump sum to every boss rather than means- testing the bonus: looking into the finances of thousands of businesses would be painstaking and cost millions in civil servants’ time.But his generosity puts the onus on companies to do the right thing and take the cash onlythey really need it.John Lewis and William Hill are two firms reported to have joined Primark in turning down the offer.The pressure is on others to follow.WE are staggered by a damning report revealing that there are as many as , modern slaves living in Britain.The eye-watering figure is ten times the official number accepted by the Government — and should leave a bitter taste in the mouths of both local government chiefs and the Home Secretary.If Britain is to be the “beacon of freedom and human rights” promised in the Tory manesto, Whitehall has to take minimum wage enforcement seriously.And councils must carry out rigorous health and safety checks in factories.It won’t be simple.But a civilised country can’t sit back and watch while desperate people are worked to the bone.LABOUR’S reaction to the report into Priti Patel’s conduct at the Home Office is nothing short of laughable.When Speaker John Bercow was up to his eyeballs in bullying allegations, opposition MPs happily looked the other way because they knew he was their best chance of blocking Brexit.But now that a report has all but cleared the Home Secretary of mis- conduct, they’re in a righteous fury.We didn’t know it was possible to develop morals so quickly.GOOD on MP Ian Lavery for launching a petition to give a posthumous honour to  World Cup hero Jack Charlton.It seemed unfair that Big Jack was never made a Sir, unlike his younger brother Bobby or their fellow England teammate Geoff Hurst.It shouldn’t need a Russian linesman to put this one right.GOT a story title: masterchef its all cooking with wokes not woks
story: The cook was Dominic ­Little-wood, the venue Battersea’s Cinnamon Kitchen, which suddenly began filling with an acrid stench and a cloud of battery acid after he accidentally baked an egg-timer instead of a naan bread.Diners coughed, waiters bolted for the front door and Sam Quek shouted: “What time is it, Dom ”But before anyone could answer or staff were hospitalised, the fire was out and the fun was over for another  years.This is, after all, Celebrity MasterChef, a relentless, formula-driven monster of a show where spontaneity is rarely on the menu.What you’ve got instead are two adequate hosts, John Torode and Gregg Wallace, organising endless rounds of cooking that lead nowhere except more rounds of cooking.Until eventually, several months down the line, someone is declared the winner and then turns up on the next series judging the food and generally acting like they’re Gordon Ramsay.Normally, though, you’ll know exactly who that’s going to be, weeks in advance, as the booking process is as regimented as everything  on this BBC show and designed to fulfil quotas as much it is to entertain.Every week there are five contestants and one must be a clumsy, have-a-go bloke, in the Dom mould, who’d clearly be far more at home shting pianos in a PG Tips advert than cooking.Form also dictates there’s a tiresomely “competitive” sports-person, like Sam Quek , a completely anonymous box-ticker, who turns out to be Karen Gibson, the choir-conductor at Meghan and Harry’s wedding, and Quadrophenia star Phil Daniels fulfilling the role of “the one you actually recognise and like”.The sucker-punch, however, is “the one you neither recognise nor like”, who ­generally comes from the attention- seeking end of the reality market.In this instance it’s someone called Baga Chipz, who caused a ripple or two on Ru Paul’s Drag Race, last year and now clearly thinks: “I’m the new Dame Edna.”There are worrying signs some people at the BBC may agree as well, because Baga was treated with a certain reverence by John and Gregg and referred to by the pronouns “she” and “her” despite the fact that underneath all that make-up there isa bloke called Leo Loren.Underneath all that make-up, it ­transpires, there’s also a signicant ego as viewers discovered when Baga Cement left the show, at a canter, declaring: “I can bring the comedy gold and telly, but I can’t cook.”Dom was next off and I was almost sad to see him go as, quite apart from melting an egg-timer, he’d produced one of my favourite ever MasterChef dishes — chicken stir fry in a ­hollowed-out pineapple.You wouldn’t want to tread in it, let alone eat it, obviously, but the show needs these distractions.Without them, Celebrity MasterChef tells you only two things: Where the celebs are at and where the BBC’s head is at.Where it should be at, of course, is dreaming up bold and imaginative new formats to see us through this dficult time.What it’s actually doing at the moment, though, is dreaming up bold and imaginative new ways to tick boxes.Starting tomorrow, when Celebrity ­MasterChef welcomes its first blind ­contestant, Amar Lat.“What time is it, Dom ”Bloody Chico time, probably. MORE than a week on from ITV’s Bullseye revival, with Alan Carr, I’m still brooding over this Epic Gameshow debacle.Obvious parts of the problem were the scheduling and the format tweaks, which introduced lelines, golden darts and spinning boards as well as a whole level of irony.It wasn’t until I spent a few days watching some glorious Challenge TV repeats of the original, though, that I twigged the over-riding issue was the personnel – particularly the s audience, who were always immaculate, and the contestants, who belonged to another world, where people had proper jobsand appearing on TV was a luxury not a birthright.On Alan Carr’s version, by contrast, they were the usual over-sharing, part-building show-offs we’ve come to expect from gameshows.On the  series, however, they seem almost unnaturally shy and have definitely arrived at the studio to win a car and some money rather than share details of their private or professional lives.It could be, of course, that they’re slightly in awe of Jim Bowen.Neither before nor since has there ever been anyone quite like the original host, who is both deliberately and accidentally hilarious.A man visibly surprised when one of the female contestants hits the right target and utterly thunderstruck when another responds correctly to the question: “Can you name the banned South African political party Oliver Tambo is a member of ”“The African National Congress.” “WOW! You are a clever girl, Sue.”It’s a little bit patronising, admittedly and he’d be hauled through every kangaroo court in the country for saying that out loud now.But I’ll take Jim’s innocent version of television before I take ’s joyless, humourless woke wasteland all day long, thanks very much. It’s a happier place.INCIDENTALLY, Loose Women, Janet Street- Porter: “If I was an animal I’d be a terrapin.”What’s technically known as horse-s***.MEANWHILE, on episode three of Celebrity Snoop Dogs, a pug called Colin is snfing around a weight-training room as Channel ’s Kevin McCloud builds to the big reveal.“More eye-catching, though, is that plaque behind the microphone. Could it belong to ­someone who’s good at making people laugh “It’s Russell Kane!” No, it couldn’t.HOW television works .Someone a BBC continuity announcer described as “the wonderful Maxine Peake” starred in last week’s Talking Heads, a fortnight after sharing an anti-Semitic conspiracy theory about George Floyd’s death, with The Independent.Miriam Margolyes s to the Beeb shortly, with her Almost Australian travelogue, despite telling Channel ’s Last Leg she wanted the Prime Minister to die of coronavirus.But actor Laurence Fox is unemployable and considered a public pariah, by the industry, because he told Question Time that Britain was “the most tolerant, lovely country in Europe”.One rule for one, quite another for Corbynistas.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Asteroid  Audrey is named after which actress ”Marina: “Kim Basinger.”Tenable, Warwick Davis: “Name the ten largest countries in South America.” Devon: “Hungary.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “In  -year-old Judit Polgar became the youngest ­international grandmaster of which board game ”Helena: “Monopoly.”Ben Shephard: “Mayo is the Spanish word for which month of the year ”Rick: “March.”GOOD Morning Britain, Monday, Piers: “What about this  At my local Italian ­restaurant, on Saturday, after all this showing-each- other-more-kindness talk, there were  no-shows.”Then Piers turned up. Problem solved. So what about it HAVING failed to conquer Hollywood or overthrow international capitalism Russell Brand took on a slightly more manageable project, last week.A cameo in Neighbours where he literally bumped into Toadie, eating a muffin, at the Harold Bishop cafe.“You’re Russell Brand! What are you doing here in Erinsborough ”“Well, you know,” said Brand, “Get Him To The Greek, The Trews, socialism, Ed Miliband. It all went horribly wrong.“So it was either this or a Postcode Lottery advert, with Jeff Brazier.”Actually, he said no such thing.He made a funny, self-mocking speech about the irony of mobile phones being “emblems of interconnectivity, yet we’re more atomised, adrt and lost than ever before”, then went to order a coffee.And I’ve got no hesitation in saying, I think it’s his finest ever work.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fast fashion firms smarten act end modern slavery
story: This apparent modern slavery has no place in fashion. It has no place anywhere. It is often a breach of human rights. It is often illegal.So it is understandable that many of us are questioning why this is happening – and, by extension, what our role is in this.Has our desire for cheap and cheerful fashion created this sickening practice  Are we somehow to blame for insisting we will only pay as little as possible for everything Should we — as some smarmy “influencers” suggest — be boycotting anyone who sells cheap clothes The simple answer is: NoOf course, in an ideal world, we’d all be buying top quality, ethically sourced garments that last a letime.But that’s just not going to happen. Most people just can’t afford to. And we like to keep up with trends while at the same time paying the bills. There is nothing wrong with that.Our love of fashion keeps the economy going.Fashion is the UK’s largest creative industry. It provides jobs for almost as many people as the financial sector and is one of the most female-dominated industries in the world.Around , people work in the UK fashion industry and approximately  per cent of garment workers are women.Livelihoods are at stakewe decide to boycott fashion brands because of their bad practices.The answer is for fast fashion firms like Boohoo and Quiz to do the work and get their houses in order. This is on them.And big firms like Boohoo — a business worth £.billion — are not without means. They have the resources to make changes.They need to perform due diligence on who is making their clothes — they must forensically examine the whole supply chain, from contractors to sub-contractors and anyone  who has a hand in how this stuff comes to market.Decent wages must be the norm. They must be transparent and tell us, the consumer, what they know.This is not rocket science. It is already happening.The Fashion Transparency Index  ranks  of the biggest global fashion brands according to how much information they provide about their suppliers, supply chain policies and practices and social and environmental impact.Retailers are scored on their transparency across five key areas: Policy and commitments, governance, traceability, supplier assessment and remediation and spotlight issues.HM, one of the largest fashion retailers in the world, is currently top of The Fashion Transparency Index.Stung by allegations that its clothes had been made by child labour in Myanmar — with some paid as little as p an hour — it last year built a new tracking system so consumers can find out where each garment is made.Marks  Spencer also scored highly. It introduced an ethical trading programme including audits of its supply chain in the Nineties.Eleven more brands in the Fashion Index revealed details of their processing facilities — where finishing, dyeing and laundering take place — in  compared to .And ten brands disclosed their raw material suppliers in , compared with just one in .Of course this isn’t just a fast fashion problem. It is industry-wide.What customers need from all brands is transparency, as this leads to accountability and ultimately change.Soyou do want to spend your hard-earned cash on fast fashion, only shop at places where you know they are doing their bit to ensure things are more ethically sourced.AS much as I love new clothes, fast fashion has had its day.Two brands have recently been at the centre of allegations that garments are being made or packed in dire working conditions in Leicester.Boohoo has paid a heavy price for these claims, with more than a billion pounds wiped off the value of its shares.Today, it suffered another big fall after a leading investor sold out on ethical grounds.And rival Quiz was sucked into the growing storm. It has suspended a supplier after claims that a factory in Leicester offered a worker just £ an hour to make its clothes.Quiz admitted that the situation, which it is investigating, is “unacceptable”.As online retailers specialising in casualwear, these companies were riding high after lockdown boosted sales. Following these allegations, the tide is turning against them.It comes after lockdown prompted many of us to reassess our lives, with the desire to be greener high on the agenda.A recent survey showed that more women were willing to make do and mend. That can’t be a bad thing.A common reason that clothes are sent to landfill is a missing button, which is simply appalling.Before buying a new dress or jacket, I now ask myself, ‘Am I going to wear this item for years ’Fashion is a global industry worth more than £trillion a year. It will clean itself up where necessary and adapt.Boohoo and Quiz have been swt to terminate relationships with rogue suppliers. Elsewhere, there is much talk of “respons-ible” and “sustainable” fashion.Don’t be surprisedthe fast fashion pack gives itself a long overdue makeover. Hopefully it will be more than the latest fad.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nicola sturgeon snp pandemic independence agenda
story: NICOLA Sturgeon and the SNP are using a global health pandemic to cynically pursue the independence agenda – and the BBC is helping them to do it.The scheming First Minister’s egregious threat to impose a border between Scotland and England is as isive as it is illegal.How can the mainstream media be giving her a free pass on such an outrageous Trump-like threat Make no mistake that this is the SNP suggesting the imposition of some sort of border that doesn’t exist by stealth between the countries of the UK under the cloak of a public health emergency.As Andrew Bowie – the Scottish vice chairman of the Tory party – told my talkRADIO show yesterday such a move would put thousands of Scottish jobs in the hospitality and tourism industry who rely on visits from England in jeopardy.But luckily he said the UK Government will not “stand by and let that happen”.Sturgeon’s dangerous position adds to her constant undermining of the UK government, which sees the SNP loudly criticise any new moves introduced by Westminster only to follow suit a fortnight later.Unsurprisingly, the BBC is buying into the SNP’s narrative hook, line and sinker.Scottish Editor Sarah Smith used the flagship UK pm news bulletin last night to broadcast a feature that was nothing short of a Sturgeon puff piece, lacking in any balance or criticism of her appalling early response to this pandemic.There was no mention of the anaemic Scottish testing regime, the cover up of an early outbreak or the devastating care home death toll.Instead, the Beeb decided to present as fact the idea that Scottish independence is an almost inevitable response to this health crisis.Hardly. Scotland’s government has had to be propped up every step of the way by Westminster.Sturgeon is a good TV performer, I’ll give her that.She’s adored by the international media in the same way New Zealand’s Jacinda Ardern is. But the facts on the ground do not match the rhetoric.Anda right-wing politician was suggesting the introduction of a border blocking free movement by citizens of the UK we would never hear the end of it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: banning huawei from uks 5g network is a good day for britain and a great day for freedom
story: People must be under no illusion: Huawei is to all intents and purposes a Chinese state company.Nothing that the company does can go against the Chinese Communist Partythat rules that state.And given this fact, it was not just wrong but reckless of the UK to even think of having the company involved in the creation of our sensitive networks.Now we will inevitably pay more for G as costs rise by £billion — and we will have to wait a further two to three years for it to be rolled out. Of course, whatever the cost becomes, it is less than the cost of the threat to our national security and is a price we must pay. We were warned repeatedly by all of our allies about involving Huawei in our communications network.In recent years, I have heard first-hand from each of our intelligence-sharing partners in the so-called “Five Eyes” network . All of these countries, our closest allies, have been deeply worried by Britain’s decision. All have warned that this country — and our relationships with our allies — would be compromisedwe allowed Huawei such access. We would have been vulnerable, they warned.Bizarrely, Theresa May ignored this advice, then Boris Johnson’s government originally went further down this terrible road.This, despite the fact that other companies — including US firms — could have provided just the same technology, without the same security risks.And, key sources tell me, all for the same price. Still the Government snubbed our allies, alarmed our friends, and stuck to their decision.Privately it was briefed out that our own security services were confident of their ability to get backdoor access to see what Huawei would be doing and to control any covert activity. But all of this seemed a ridiculously high-risk venture. And for what exactly  Fortunately, that bizarre decision got reversed yesterday.Several factors have contributed to it. The first is an obvious change in relations towards China that is going on around the world. Covid- has played a part. China — unwittingly or carelessly — gave the world a virus which has all but halted our economies.The CCP’s lies and cover-ups during this devastating period have meant that all of us have been confined to our houses for months — and not just those who have contracted the coronavirus that came from Wuhan.In the months and years ahead, all of us will be poorer because of the CCP’s lies. The state has disappeared its own scientists. It allowed travel even after it knew what it was dealing with. It lied about the nature of the virus.And other members of the Five Eyes network have suggested that the evidence points clearly to the virus having been created in a Chinese laboratory.President Trump and his Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, have rightly made an issue of this. Both have been warning for years about the instability of China as a partner. As recent events in Hong Kong should remind us, China is a one-party, totalitarian state. It rules by dictatorship and terror. Of course, it is also highly technologically skilled and financially ever more dominant.The CCP seeks to make China the world’s leading power. Washington is — rightly — determined to stop that. And this country —we value freedom and the rule of law, as we always have — should seek to stop that too.This means, among much , denying China and Chinese state companies from extending their grip in countries like ours.For years, Chinese companies have stolen information, ripped off s, and otherwise acted completely unlawfully. They have engaged in espionage and information theft on an industrial scale.Some people might look at yesterday’s decision and think it a small, technical matter. It isn’t.Not only is it a decision with far-reaching consequences for this country’s security. It is also a signal of which side this country will be on in one of the most important tussles of our day.Everywhere China seeks to extend its power is an area where freedom recedes.Yesterday was a bad day for Huawei, a good day for Britain and a great day for freedom.Q: WHAT is the new ruling on Huawei A: From the end of this year, telecoms firms will not be able to buy any new Huawei hardware, such as antennas, to put into their G networks. By the end of , all Huawei equipment must be stripped out of the UK’s G networks.Q: Why is G important A: It will be ten times faster than G and allow more complicated technology, such as driverless cars, to operate.Q: What is Huawei currently used for A: The firm is the leading provider of technology needed to operate wireless networks that provide the G signal on our mobile phones. They were going to be used for “non-core” equipment in the G network. Instead European firms Nokia or Erion are likely to provide the hardware.Q: Can I still use my Huawei mobile phone A: Yes. There is no plan to ban its handsets.Q: Will the ban affect my phone signal A: Some telecom firms have warned that stripping out all Huawei hardware too quickly could result in a temporary loss of signal in some places, but other experts say this concern has been exaggerated.Q: Does this affect full fibre broadband connections A: Not at the moment. The Government’s security advisers have only recommended “transitioning away” from Huawei when it comes to fibre networks.Q: Will I have to replace a Huawei router in my home A: The router is not part of the G infrastructure and won’t be affected.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wear a mask to the shops its not a big deal
story: The moaning over their compulsory use in shops from next Friday is ridiculous.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSome pretend it is a grotesque assault on our civil liberties — a “monstrous imposition”, one daft Tory backbencher called it. It really isn’t. Nor will refusing to wear one make someone a hero. If their reluctance is just vanity or embarrassment, they should get over themselves. A mask’s main purpose is to protect ­others. That’s reason enough.That’s not to say we don’t have a few doubts. Health Secretary Matt Hancock says masks “give people more confidence to shop safely”. Well, perhaps. But one new survey indicates that half of families will be scared away from shopsthe Government really considers them that dangerous.We only hope they are vastly outnumbered by those who DO feel safer — or the new edict will strangle our feeble­-looking recovery instead of boosting it.Plus, we have to ask: when will the new rules end  Is there a plan The Government was farcically late imposing them. The Sun backed masks when there were , new UK Covid cases a day. It’s now a tenth of that and the risk of catching it very, very small. How low must daily infections be before we ditch masks . . .     Zero On balance, we still believe their routine use, along with social distancing and hand washing, are our three best forms of self-defence. For now.But normality mustrapidly or our economic prospects are unthinkably grim.  THOSE dire prospects are starkly exposed in the latest woeful economic data.It should be no surprise that growth saw only a slight uptick in May. Shops and pubs still weren’t open. Even so, a . per cent rise barely registers against the . per cent fall in March and April.There’s even worse news on jobs: unemployment is forecast to triple by Christmas, while our deficit hits a mind-boggling £billion for the year.We celebrated when Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane said a swt V-shaped recovery was under way.We now wonder what he’s been smoking.FOR a decade Britain cosied up to a ­Chinese regime which has increasingly revealed itself to be malign.The belated Huawei U-turn must be just a first step in reversing that trend. title: farmhouse sanctuaries sprawling 11m ranches 480k horses and cattle celebs shunning city living for the country
story: Especiallyyou’re a multimillion-pound celebrity, willing to splash the cash on a luxurious ranch or farm retreat.Forget camping, or roughing it in a cramped cabin - here, we take a look at the celebrities shunning the bustle of the city in favour of a more relaxed rural setting, albeit still on a blow-out budget…A far cry from their £m Hollywood Hidden Hills mega mansion estate, Kim and Kanye are said to have loved le on their £m, , acre ranch in Wyoming so much, they splurged another £m on a second , acre property in the same area.Situated  miles from Yellowstone National Park, it’s where the family have spent much of lockdown, and the original luxurious sprawling country estate boasts two fishing lakes, a working horse barn and cattle.In the past Kim has described it as “the prettiest place you’ve seen in your entire le,” and it’s clear the family have developed a love for the great outdoors - albeit from the comfort of their impressive estate, which boasts a saloon and a restaurant on site.The family also own  Friesian horses - a rare breed which can reportedly cost up to £k each - and Kim has relished the opportunity to have her kids learn how to horse ride and be at one with nature.While the Beckhams can boast a y property portfolio - featuring a London townhouse, Dubai beach pad and Miami penthouse - they chose to spend lockdown in their stunning rural retreat.Their Cotswolds ranch was a Grade II-listed farmhouse that was converted into a sprawling country mansion when they bought it in December  for a hefty £.million.David and Victoria have gone with a traditional ranch-like aesthetic for their not-so humble abode, which features exposed brick walls, huge open fireplaces, and wooden beams running across the low ceilings - It’s cool.“I’ve always been interested in animals.”Kristin Cavallari rose to fame on popular MTV series Laguna Beach, but it seems the reality star was only too happy to swap the golden sands of Calornia for the £.m farm house she bought with now-estranged husband Jay Cutler in Nashville, Tennessee.The pair purchased the , square foot, eight bed hobby farm in , which also boasts  acres of land, a chicken coop, horse stables and a goat barn.The daily farmyard chores provided content for their reality TV show, Very Cavallari - including removing poo from their brood of  baby chick’s behinds.And it seems the task was an eye opener for the mum of three, with Kristin saying: “Living out on a farm, I’ve learned quite a few things and one of those is that, baby chicks, you have to clean their butts … becausethey can’t poop, they’ll die.”Queen of TV chat shows and worth a cool bn, obviously Oprah Winfrey wouldn’t buy just one country retreat.She has a £m ranch, named ‘The Promised Land’ in Montecito which is a property set on  acres of land, with both mountain and ocean views.Also within her property portfolio are a £m, -acre horse farm in the same area featuring four bedrooms, five baths, a pool and a filled fish pond, as well as a  acre farm in Hawaii.The star has a particular connection to the country, having grown up on a small farm in Mississippi, where her grandmother grew all their food.Writing about growing up on Oprah, the presenter said: “We churned the butter, we milked the cows, we killed the hogs, we cured the meat in the smokehouse. Above all, we tended our little garden.“Thats where most of what we ate came from. And now Ive ed to that way of living: We eat whats from the garden.”When not living in LA, actor Chris Pratt spends his time at his rural farm house in Washington, raising sheep, two pigs called Tim and Faith, and a herd of cows.In fact, the -year-old star’s flock of livestock are award-winning, with one ewe’s fleece taking home a blue ribbon at the local farming show.Speaking about farm le, his pregnant we Katherine Schwarzenegger told E! News: “It’s a fun adjustment. I have grown up with a bunch of dferent animals, so it feels very comfortable and at home and just a beautul part of le.”While plenty of celebs are hopping on the farming bandwagon, one thing’s for sure after taking a closer look at their rural retreats.It’s not like any camping holiday we’ve been on.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british nuclear submarine nearly ploughed into a passenger ferry carrying 282 people
story: Disaster was only avoided after the ferry’s crew spotted a periscope poking over the waves and took emergency evasive action.The massive Stena Superfast VII ferry and an unidentied submarine were - metres from a collision, an investigation has found.A report by the Marine Accident Investigation Branch slammed the sub’s commanders for “not taking sufficient action” to keep the vessels apart.The sub’s commanders thought the ferry, which had  passengers and  crew, was slower and further away that it was, as they crossed the Irish Sea in Nov .“The submarines control room team overestimated the ferrys range and underestimated its speed,” the report, published todaysaid.This was an unsafe event and placed the ferrys passengers and crew, as well as the submarine and its crew, in immediate danger.”The Navy refused to identy the name or type of the submarine, which was based at HMS Faslane in Scotland. But the silent service insisted there were no nuclear safety issues.A Royal Navy spokesperson said: “Ensuring safety at sea is a top priority for the Royal Navy, which is why we welcome this report and have already taken action to tighten our training and procedures.”The Navy has two types of submarines, which are m and m long.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: one in three firms lay off staff furlough
story: The British Chamber of Commerce said that an historic cash crunch is pushing businesses to tighten up their budgets and let staff go as the country struggles to recover from the lockdown.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAccording to poll done of , businesses by BCC and TotalJobs,  per cent of businesses expect they will have to make job cuts in the next three months - the highest number on record. The revelations stoke fears the Chancellors furlough scheme has only been masking widespread job losses in Britain.But as many as  per cent of businesses will keep their staff on after Rishi Sunak offered to pay £ for each furloughed worker that is brought back to work until at least January. Only  per cent of firms are looking to increase the size of their workforce.Mr Sunak extended the furlough scheme, but employers will need to start to make pension and national insurance contributions from next month. From September businesses will have to pay  per cent of their staffs wages, with the Government scaling back their support from  per cent to  per cent. By October they will be asked to pay  per cent with a  per cent contribution from the Government.The job losses will be felt most in bigger firms - around  per cent of large firms with over  employees expect to make lay offs, compared to  per cent of micro firms with fewer than  employees. The percentage of firms actively trying to bring on new employees dropped to the lowest level on record at  per cent. Since the lockdown began in March there are , fewer people in jobs, according to new figures by the ONS.The number of actual hours worked by employees between March and May this year was down by . million - or . per cent - to . million hours, the biggest drip since estimates began in . Business Secretary Alok Sharma said this morning: The figures out there, that is iniduals who will be finding it very dficult at this time. But he said the Treasurys coronavirus schemes - included the furlough scheme - has helped save jobs. He said: There is support out there. But I completely acknowledge this is going to be a very dficult time for lots of people out there who are facing a huge amount of worry.The job losses also makes the Governments challenge of getting to spend money on British restaurants, pubs and shops to bolster the economy all the more dficult. Boris Johnson is gearing up to announce his plan to get people back into offices and onto public transport to help people behave and spend more normally. The public will be advised to still avoid using public transport during peak rush hour times of -am, which will still be categorised as “essential travel only”.Instead the public will be told to use public transport outside of rush hours - between am and pm and after pm and encouraged to walk and cycleat all possible during peak times.A Whitehall source said: “We are looking at the messaging - it will look at grading the times people travel.“There is a lot of extra capacity on public transport that is not being used.“People will be told thatyou avoid the rush hour, the crush times, it is safe to travel.BCC Co-Executive Director Hannah Essex said: “Many businesses are suffering from an historic cash crunch and reduced demand, meaning firms will still face tough decisions despite welcome interventions made in the Summer Statement.“The government should consider additional support for employers before the Autumn Budget to reduce the overall cost of employment and prevent substantial redundancies.Measures could include a temporary cut in employer National Insurance Contributions and support to upskill and reskill employees as businesses adapt to change.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: finger meat pie brazil
story: Victor Santos, , spat out the chopped off joint - which still had the nail intact - and screamed with horror before being physically sick following the discovery.The schoolboy’s parents said they ordered a selection of savoury pastries with assorted fillings for home delivery last Saturday from a local takeaway in São Paulo, Brazil.As they sat down to eat, the boy picked one of the pastries and, when he took his first bite, he found the severed finger in it.Eduardo do Carmo Santos, owner of the Companhia da Esfiha, apparently admitted to police that “one ofemployees cut off the top of his fore finger while slicing pepperoni.”The chef, named as Jesus de Souza Silva, , was allegedly using a meat slicer when the accident happened.Mr do Carmo Santos claimed: “ searched for his missing fingertip in the food, on the kitchen floor and in the equipment used to cut the pepperoni but couldn’t find it.“He was taken to hospital for emergency treatment and we closed the restaurant for a couple days.”Images show the pallid fingertip with the unbroken nail encased in shrivelled skin, after it was subjected to high temperatures in the oven.Cartilage and the ends of jagged bones can be seen from the underside of the severed finger.The takeaway - which produces a range of pizzas and savoury pastries - reopened on Saturday and began taking orders again without apparently reporting the work accident to the area’s health and safety authority.That same evening two officers, out on patrol, found the shocked family gathered outside the snack bar angrily demanding answers about the finger found in the food.The schoolboy’s distressed mum, Elisangela, , reportedly said in a statement to cops: “We ordered a box of esfihas by phone for home delivery. When it came my son picked out one of the pastries which is his favourite.“He took his first bite and found something strange, hard and fleshy in his mouth. He immediately spat it out because this is not the type of thing you would expect to find in an esfiha.“When we inspected it, we were horried to discover the piece was the top of a human finger.“My son was ill when he realised what had been in his mouth and that he had nearly swallowed it. He is totally shaken up and is suffering nightmares after this appalling experience.”A team of health and safety experts from the Consumer Protection Institute visited the takeaway within hours and ordered it to close following its apparent failure to meet acceptable hygiene standards and safety conditions.The owner faces substantial fines for inadequate consumer standards along with criminal charges of culpable bodily injury and endangering the health and le of a minor and worker.The evidence has been collected by the Institute of Forensic Medicine and is being examined as part of the criminal proceedings. The teenager’s mum said her son will never eat another meat pastry again.The family has been advised to take legal action and seek compensation against the restaurant for risking the teenager’s health and endangering his mental stability.The injured chef was taken to hospital and has already been discharged with remedial treatment continuing at home.The bakery has been contacted for a response.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann suspect christian b release decision
story: Christian B, , is currently in jail serving  months for drug offences and last month was eligible for parole after serving two thirds of his sentence.In December he was convicted of raping a  year old American woman in  in her own home just a few minutes walk from where Maddie was taken two years later in Praia da Luz, Portugal.Today his lawyer Friedrich Fulscher argued that protocols in the use of the European Arrest Warrant were breached when Germany secured his extradition from Italy to Germany in .Mr Fulscher argued on a technicality that speciality protection lawwas broken because he was extradited for the drugs conviction but then subsequently put on trial for raping the elderly woman. Christian B was later sentenced to seven years for the rape but his legal team say title: headaches most common coronavirus symptom
story: Experts say  per cent of people who experienced any Covid- symptoms reported having a sore head.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe research, by Imperial College London, also found that loss of taste or smell were each more common than a persistent cough.Scientists also discovered that just three in  people who test positive for coronavirus show any symptoms at all.The findings are based on data from , volunteers aged over five across the UK in May.A blocked nose was the second most commons symptom - affecting just over half of those who reported any symptoms in the week before testing positive for Covid.Meanwhile, exactly one third of those who experienced symptoms had diarrhoea.As for the symptoms on the NHSs official coronavirus list, one in five of those who reported symptoms had a fever while  per cent had a new, persistent cough.While a loss of smell and taste affected  per cent and  per cent respectively.It comes as experts at Kings College London called for skin rashes to be added to the official list of symptoms.In a separate large community-based study, conducted with Zoe Global Ltd, they found . per cent of people who had tested positive for Covid had also reported having a skin rash.Mario Falchi, who led the team, said that while skin rashes are far less common than a fever, they are much more specic and last longer.His team said that while coronavirus is primarily a respiratory illness, it also targets multiple organs - including the skin - and urged people to be on the look out for itchy hands and feet.  The Imperial report provides insight into infections between May  and June , comparing geography, age, sex, ethnicity, key worker status and symptoms.Beyond the diminished rate of infection, the research found young adults aged  to  were more likely to test positive than other age groups.It also showed there were on average  positive cases for every , people, with an overall reproduction number of . - lower than previously reported.People of Asian ethnicity were also more likely to test positive than those of white ethnicity, while people working in care homes were at greater risk of being infected during lockdown than the general population.The report also showed anyone who had recent contact with a known Covid- case was  times more likely to test positive than those with no such contact, emphasising the importance of contact tracing in keeping the spread of the virus under control.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the study is crucial to the countrys ongoing battle with coronavirus.This ambitious testing programme will help us better understand the spread of the virus to date, predict how it may spread in the future and inform our response to the pandemic, he said.It shows the impact our national lockdown efforts have had and demonstrates that we have taken the right actions at the right time.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.As a country we have made great strides towards beating this virus but we mustnt take our foot off the pedal, and such studies will be vital as we continue to fight this virus.The study, which has been upscaled and repeated for June, will now undergo peer review before a final report is published.Plans are currently underway for a second large-scale study, which will use antibody tests to determine how much of the general public has been infected with Covid- in the past.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester lockdown decision today hancock
story: The Citys Mayor today blasted the Government for not getting them coronavirus data quick enough - ahead of an official decision later today.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Health Secretary will make a statement to MPs at pm today - which is expected to include an update for the city.He will make an important statement providing a coronavirus update, the Commons Speaker has told MPs.Sir Peter Soulsby said this morning that having the full picture would have prevented a lockdown from ever being necessary and said the people would be furiousit continued.The city was the first in the UK to be put back into lockdown last month after a spike in cases.And the Health Secretary is expected to review the measures later today.Decisions about where the lockdown will apply will be made by local authorities - with the help of the Joint Biosecurity Centre.Testing centres swooped on the city and people were encouraged to stay home. Shops were shut up again and pubs and restaurants did not open on July  ass in the rest of the country.Asked what his reaction would bethe Government announced a further two-week lockdown, the citys mayor told BBC Radio Lecieser: I thinkwe are told that, there are going to be an awful lot of Leicester people who are very angry indeed.It was quite clear that it was a political decision taken without the advice of Public Health Englandto take us into this lockdown in the first place.Itll be a political decision to let us out and the sooner that political decision is taken, the better.Sir Peter also told Sky News: Im just very angry and frustrated because weve now, well into the lockdown, begun to get some data from the government that actually shows where the virus is and where it isnt in the city.Weve been asking for this for weeks.He said there were some clusters of the virus in parts of the city, but most of it was now corona-free.If we had this before, we could have used it to intervene - as Blackburn and other places are using it to intervene now - with those neighbourhoods to prevent the lockdown ever being necessary.A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said today: As this data confirms, coronavirus cases in Leicester were signicantly higher than other parts of the country – and we took clear and decisive action to save lives.“We are working closely with the local authorities to ensure that these measures are only in place as long as is necessary, and we will set out the next steps by  July.”The Government has stressed that data has been provided to the Directors of Public Health throughout the incident.The lockdown covers the city of Leicester as well as surrounding areas including Birstall, Beaumont Leys, Glenfield and South Wigston. It has been suggested that families living in closer quarters, combined with a higher population of people whose English is a second language, may have contributed to the spike in cases.Workers in cramped clothing factories have also been blamed, with Police and the National Crime Agency investigating possible links to modern slavery.But Sir Peter told Sky News there is no evidence whatsoever to show coronavirus was being transmitted in clothing factories.Theres nothing in the data that suggests it is transmitting in places of work, he said.The most recent data from PHE shows that the number of new cases of coronavirus per , population in Leicester has dropped from . in the seven days to July  to . in the seven days to July .It was . in the seven days to June , just before the local lockdown was imposed.Health Secretary Matt Hancock met Leicester Mayor Sir Peter Soulsby on Monday to discuss the issues.Mr Hancock told the House of Commons on Monday they would look at  days worth of information on case numbers in Leicester on Thursday - and make an announcement about changes as soon as possible.He said: Well look aton Thursday of this week and make a public announcement as soon as is reasonably possible about whether and any changes can be made to the situation in Leicester.Mr Hancock revealed flare-ups are being swtly and silently dealt with.He said more than  local actions are being taken across the country each week.Professor Jonathan Van-Tam said a lockdown exit plan for the city depends on value judgments by public health professionals on when coronavirus rates are consistently and obviously falling.Mr Van-Tam told the BBC that data published on Saturday showed the city is really quite an outlier compared with anywhere  in the country.The latest figures for Leicester show a seven-day rate of  cases per , people, compared with figures of . for Leicestershire as a whole, . in Derby and . in Nottingham.Mr Van-Tam told the BBC: The situation has improved but it needs to go further.He said that, while it would not be his decision to end the lockdown, doing so cant be rushed.Pressed on whether Leicesters lockdown is likely to be lted, Mr Van-Tam said: With any of these things, usually the way that one approaches them from a public health perspective is to take a phased approach.Normally you dont just go from having the brakes on heavily to just taking the brakes off completely.I think thats a reasonable expectation to set.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pendle lancashire coronavirus blackburn
story: County health officials have warned the area, which is home to around , people, is at risk of going back into lockdownthe virus continues to spread rapidly.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesPendle had an infection rate of . new cases per , people in the week ending July , after there was a spike in new cases on July  and .Figures in Pendle jumped from . to . per , people in just seven days. Health officials have warned locals that they must act now or be placed back under strict lockdown measures like those currently in force in Leicester.It comes after new measures were put in force in Blackburn which is  miles away from Pendle including a limit on how many people can meet indoors. Lancashires director of public health Dr Sakthi Karunanithi has now given an early warning for people in Pendle to wash their hands often, stick to social distancing and wear masks in indoor public places.Dr Karunanithi admitted there had been a slight increase in Covid- cases and said We need your help now to... keep Pendle out of lockdown.It can feel like things are back to normal, but we are still in the middle of a pandemic and there is risk for the virus to come back.Pendle Council said: The overall rate and number of cases remains relatively low, but there are signs of ongoing household transmission.This comes as Blackburn with Darwen Council - just  miles away from Pendle -has enforced a limit on the number of people allowed to visit a household in an effort to avoid a Leicester-style coronavirus lockdown.The move is among new measures introduced to curb the spread of infection in the Lancashire authority amidst a worrying spike in covid- cases.The measures were announced yesterday by the councils director of public health Dominic Harrison. The restrictions include a limit of two people from the same household allowed to visit another home.And as part of the new rules, residents are being told to wear cloth face coverings in all enclosed public spaces, including workplaces, libraries, museums, health centres and hair and beauty salons. Health officials also called on locals to elbow bump with anyone outside of their immediate family, while small shops will be given updated public protection advice to ensure social distancing.A mobile testing unit has also been set up at Witton Park Academy in the area, as well as a facility at Royal Blackburn Hospital.Residents have also been told they do not need to have symptoms to take a test.Figures published yesterday showed that Blackburn had  cases per , people in the seven days to July .This marked a signicant increase from . cases per , in the seven days to July .It puts the authority at third on the list of highest weekly rates, but still behind Leicester which has a rate of . cases per ,.Leicester went back into lockdown on June  after a spike in infections, with all non-essential retail stores closed as well as hospitality venues which reopened in the rest of the UK on July .Last weekend, the government drew up a list of  councils facing the worst outbreaks in England - which included Blackburn with Darwen local authority as well as Bradford, Kirklees and Rochdale.Topping the list is Leicester, followed by Rochdale and Bradford in the ranking for the areas with the highest rate of coronavirus cases.Blackburn is fth on the list - but the council have now taken the precautions which will hopefully mean the town wont have to go into a local lockdown.The data shows that Covid infections are rising in other places though with Blackburn, Bedford and Peterborough now on the hotspot danger list.Health officials said that new Covid cases are highest in the East and Midlands and Yorkshire and Humber.Government officials have not yet laid out what metrics will be used to impose further lockdowns.However,reports that ministers are considering a threshold of  weekly positive tests per , people, based on a scheme rolled out in Germany. Mr Harrison said it was up to everyone in the town to ensure a dreaded local lockdown was avoided.He said: These steps will help and we are appealing to everyone in Blackburn with Darwen to follow them to protect themselves and their loved ones.If we dont, a local lockdown, like in Leicester, becomes a very real possibility.We can only avoid further lockdown measureswe work together.He added that a rise in targeted testing would spark a surge in case numbers in the next week to ten days.But should these continue to rise after two weeks, authorities would consider reversing some of the national lockdown lting measures locally one by one.Council leader Mohammed Khan said: I can reassure all local residents that the council is working with dferent agencies and organisations across the borough to help get the message out to everyone that le cannot go back to normal just yet, and we must all make sacrices to avoid a local lockdown.We are doing everything we can to get a grip on the virus, and we need everyone in Blackburn with Darwen to pull together to help us.Please continue to do your bit to stick to the rules to protect yourself and your family.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blm sculpture jen reid removed
story: Pictures from the scene in Bristol showed workers at the site at around .am.Council workers used ropes to secure the statue of Jen Reid before removing it and loading it into a recycling and skip hire lorry. The statue, by artist Marc Quinn, was put up in the early hours of Wednesday.Ms Reid, who attended the original BLM march where the statue of slave trader Colston was toppled, said yesterday: Id better get a picture before they take it down.Quinns lesize black resin and steel piece of Ms Reid was inspired after seeing a photo of her standing on the empty plinth. The sculpture, entitled A Surge of Power , was installed without the knowledge or consent of Bristol City Council.On Wednesday, Bristol mayor Marvin Rees tweeted: I understand people want expression, but the statue has been put up without permission.Anything put on the plinth outside of the process weve put in place will have to be removed.A Bristol City Council spokeswoman said today: This morning we removed the sculpture.It will be held at our museum for the artist to collect or donate to our collection.  Last month, the Edward Colston statue was dragged to the harbourside, where it was thrown into the water at Peros Bridge - named in honour of enslaved man Pero Jones who lived and died in the city.He was a merchant in the Royal African Company during the th Century.  A bronze memorial in his honour had stood in the Bristol city centre since .Colston was a philanthropist in his native Bristol and upon his death, he bequeathed his wealth to charities.His legacy can still be seen on Bristols streets, memorials and buildings.Colston played a key role in running the slave trade from Africa to the Caribbean and America during the late s.In  he became a member of the Royal African Company which at the time had a monopoly on the England and West African slave trade.By  he had risen to become the firms deputy governor.During his time at the company, it is believed to have transported around , African men, women and children as slaves.The council retrieved the statue, which will be displayed in the citys museum along with placards from the BLM protest, from the water on June .Colston worked for the Royal African Company in the th century and was later a Tory MP in Bristol. story: NewsFamily of -stone man who starved to death win permission to fight DWP in High CourtErrol Graham had just two tins of fish in his cupboard when he was found by bailfs chasing a bill. Now his daughter-in-law will argue the Department for Work and Pensions breached the lawShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsErrol Graham was found with just a couple of out-of-date tins in his cupboard " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe family of a five-stone man who starved to death after his benefits were stopped have won permission to fight the government in the High Court. Errol Grahamaposs daughter-in-law has been granted a two-day judicial review hearing to argue the governmentaposs protection for vulnerable benefit claimants was unlawful. In an important test case, Alison Turner will also ask judges to declare the Work and Pensions Secretary, Therese Coffey, breached the law by failing to properly review its policies after Errolaposs death. If she wins the judicial review, it could have profound implications for the future of Department for Work and Pensions benefit policy for the most vulnerable. A DWP spokesman said: “It would be inappropriate for us to comment further at this time.” Errol Graham weighed less than five stone when bailfs found his body in June  - eight months after his ESA disabled benefit was stopped for missing an appointment. The -year-old, who had severe mental health dficulties, had just a couple of five-year-old tins of fish in his cupboard. Mr Grahamaposs death was referred to a Serious Case Panel. But its membership is secret and the DWP has refused to sayMs Turner will be allowed to see the findings. Ms Turner said in a statement: “Errol had a long history of serious mental illness which left him severely incapacitated. When the circumstances of his death came to light we had hoped and from what the DWP stated at the inquest, we had expected that the department would review their safeguarding policies and involve us in that review. “But, incredibly, that has not happened.We deserve answers and those answers need to be public for the sake of other families - and other vulnerable benefits claimants who suffer similar mental health dficulties. “No one  should be put at risk in the same way Errol was because adequate safeguarding measures are not in place.” Mr Grahamaposs death sparked fresh calls for an independent inquiry into benefit claimantsapos deaths. The spiral towards losing his benefits began on  August , when he failed to attend a fit-for-work test for his ESA.

title: parliament could move york westminster
story: NewsParliament could move to York while Westminster renovated, Boris Johnson suggestsIn a letter, Boris Johnson says that locations outside London should be considered as a review is under way on how to handle the repair works at Parliament, which some estimates state could cost £ billionShareByShaun ConnollyOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUL News " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
